reviews.review_msg: Alderete's teaching philosophy is great if you are interested in the course material and willing to participate. Quizzes and homework are fair and answers are covered in detail in the following class.

People told me John was bad news. As a lecturer, he isnt good at explaining things. When you ask a question he either refers you to the syllabus or asks you a question in return. Very lecture heavy, but I took the course as SS in 5 weeks, instead of 13. As the course was REMOTE, he wasnt really teaching, but talking AT us - goes too fast, keep up!

John Alderete is a good professor and he knows what he's talking about, although he lacks bedside manner and most often won't answer your question if it's content-related. I took this class summer session, so it was condensed into five weeks instead of thirteen, which worked well. The homework was hard but he'll help you if you ask for it.

Horrible prof, his hand-writing is awful and his explanation is confusing , I suggest you avoid this guy if you are Asian , also, if you visit his office hour , he wont be nice to you and try to kick you out ASAP , his grading is tough and most of the time you dont know why you get wrong because there are no explanation. Class averages are C
Terrible teacher , notes are not clear , very confused...what he required book is completely not useful!

Phenomenal professor. Explains everything clearly with many examples. Exam data is given in advance, and multiple choice is right out of the notes/examples covered in class. Fair marker, and rewards critical thinking even if you're not entirely correct. Would take every linguistics course with this man if it were possible. He's brilliant.

John isn't bad at all! He's nice and his lectures are pretty fun if you have a real interest in Linguistics. I'd read the book and not get anything, but when I come to class to attend the lecture, I actually learn stuff.

Giving the final TWO weeks before the semester was over and THEN giving homework is ridiculous. Be prepared to remember specific LANGUAGE examples, even though the class is supposed to be about phonological *PROCESSES*. If I want to learn and remember specific languages, I'd be in a different class.
he took a subject i hated and thought i was terrible at and made me love it. i did really well, he is a great teacher, albeit a bit nerdy at times.
can never follow up his lecture with his notes.. but he's helpful in office hour in which he makes sure you totally understand whatever you asked

Very intelligent prof, though very boring & lack of sense of humour(he yawns during his lectures). He tries to avoid ambiguity on exams, but is very picky with your wording on definitions/essays. Exams/assignments focus on his lecture notes which he prepares before lecture.
Emotional scarring will fade away, but the big Fat F on your transcript won't.
Just read the comments below.
I feel sorry for the guy but he just can't teach.
You have to figure things out yourself, don't expect him to teach !!
No Comments
useless and can't learn anything from his lecture
No Comments
Better Left Unsaid
this is a core course, but don' t take with this professor!!!!

One problem I had was he told us up front that he didn't want to be teaching the class, that he had other things to do. Lectures were boring but Dr.Perry is very funny in his own way. The exams were fair but each question was worth a lot of points, which is difficult as phonology questions are often all or nothing.

He speaks in a monotone voice, and gives very boring lectures and very difficult assignments. He is nearly useless as he tells us to go to the TA everytime we have a question. From what I have observed, he is simply not engaged with teaching.
Fantastic lectures, so informative and clear. The class is structured very well and the assignments are helpful to learning.

Hands down the best prof in the ling department! You have to put in the work and homework, quizzes, and exams are from class materials. Go to office hours..that's my biggest piece of advice. She really cares about her students and making sure everyone understands. Speak up in class to show her you are trying.

Hard marker. Gives vague feedback. Don't take her class if you don't have to. Doesn't explain concepts well and expects you to know most things. Many people fail her class as she tests you at a very hard level with exams and assignments. Most assignments don't cover what is taught in class. You have to figure it out on your own.

She may be the best prof in the ling department. 

She is so supportive and great at explaning really large topics and by the end you will feel quite capable.

Be ready to work on assignments early to ask questions

Ash is an amazing lecturer, and she is able to make complex issues easy to understand. I definitely recommend listening to all the lectures, that's the only way to really get anything out of the class.

Ashley is a caring and passionate prof who is easy to contact really knows what she's talking about. However, the class material is quite hard and the workload is quite heavy. There are 4 assignments, 4 quizzes, weekly lecture quizzes, and 2 exams, which are marked pretty tough by her and her TA. At least she drops the worst assignment and quizzes.

If you take 321 blended with her, she is the best prof. She makes everything clear, and even if I just went to her class a few times, I got a good grade by watching videos and materials. LING 321 is really easy and interesting with Ashley.

I have no idea why they're rated so high I've had Farris twice and I've hated both classes with a passion. I pray I never have another class with them. Change assignments last minute, condescending, vague responses to questions. Don't remember anything of substance they taught. I'm an average student and didn't fail but many people fail her classes

Ashley is very well-liked and I can definitely see why but the quizzes are ridiculously hard and are more like exams than anything else. She's a tough grader too and I don't feel like you get enough time to fill in the questions. As someone who really needs time to write stuff out, I don't appreciate 20-minute quizzes I feel like that is a set up.
The professor teaches Phonology very well. However, the content of this course is quite hard. She drops the lowest score of quiz and assignment which can make you to get a better grade.

Ashley is the real deal. She cares passionately about her field, and it shows. It's important not to miss her lectures, as they're also entertaining as well as informative and interactive. She had more office hour availability than I've seen in most profs. She gave us a lot of handouts, which helped us practice what we learnt. Instant favourite.

Ashley is such an AMAZING teacher. Super down-to-earth and friendly. She's super organized and is really good at explaining things in a clear concise way. Tests are OK as long as you attended classes. She doesn't use slides, so you have to write notes, but her writing is really nice and cute :) so it's easy to follow! A+++++++++ one of my fav!!

Prof Ashley is very organized, passionate in the materials that she is teaching.Her profession is in phonology! She is always willing to give hand to students who need helps! Her midterms were fairly easy if you attend her every class! Go to her office hours as much as you can, very VERY helpful.  One of my favourite prof in SFU! All the best!

I liked his lectures a lot, but his exams were really REALLY REALLY bad.  He did not give enough practice with questions before and he always crammed too much into the tests.  I understood everything and did well, but I have a feeling most of my classmates were lost with his exams. It was his first time teaching the course tho.

Dont do this to urself!!! do not take a class with him!! u will defenitely regreat it! He needs more teaching experience~~ i dont think that he has the skills~~lectures are useless.he is unprepared or prepares too much and he has to rush thro the material

He absolutely is a smart person himself, but he does not understand that his students aren't that bright. Overall he's quite helpful at times .... but his communication with his students were not too clear regarding the area of the tests ...

If you can take this class with anyone else... do it!!! Don't let the Prof. practice his teaching skills on you!! (He needs a lot of practice!) Exams were ridiculous - don't take this course if you like phonology b/c you'll detest it afterwards.

Do not take this course with him...you'll regret it.  He's a nice prof (or tries to be) but he needs to learn how to TEACH properly. He does not understand that we are students learning at an introductory level... he thinks everybody is as smart as he is!

so-so-so hard! the 1st mid-term is "a little ok"..and the 2nd mid-term..OMG..i was like..err I didn't know how to do ALL the questions...and the assignments and notes is not helpful for the mid-terms..

Marion is friendly, down-to-earth, and caring - one of my fav profs ever. I like how her quizzes (before remote learning) are taken individually followed by groups and she saves the highest mark. However, phonology can be a tricky subject with complicated rules. Do LOTS of practice questions and make sure you understand the answers thoroughly.

Professor Caldecott was great. She always stops to make sure everyone understands and makes herself available to help despite her long commute. If I had one recommendation I would suggest posting lecture slides before class so students can read in advance because the textbook is sometimes tough to comprehend. But overall I enjoyed the class.

Marion is friendly and passionate about Linguistics but not great at articulating concepts in an easy to understand manner. The structure for the course didn't make sense because we were given small group problems before we even understood the material. This ended up wasting a lot of time that could have been spent learning how to actually do them.
